Fields.DialogueText: Capitano, I'm sorry for the delay the Italian officials caused. They wanted to make sure I was aware of my orders before they let us depart.
I wasn't expecting any trouble from the Italian government, especially not now. The Morganas are a larger threat to Italy than any normal force.
As they are to every country. I'm sorry, Capitano, but they were taking the necessary precautions to make sure I know where my loyalties lie.
And where do yours lie, if I might ask?
That's a question you don't need to ask. With Italy, of course, and with my King. Wherever he wishes me, I will go.
And with you, of course. You are my capitano.

Fields.MenuText: Those loyalties seem perfectly in order.
Which comes first, your duty to capitano or King?
I hope you put loyalty to me first while onboard.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm glad, Capitano. It's confusing to me, sometimes, to keep everything straight.
That's an impolite question to ask. I am a Belle of Italy, above all else.
Your will is to destroy the Morganas, as is my King's. Your interests align.
I'm sorry, I don't like talking about this. Politics make my head spin! We can talk more later, if you wish.
Very well. Everything is in order, then? You're ready to set sail to Spain?
Eagerly, Capitano! I'm looking forward to exploring new waters. But look, there, off the bow! Is that--?
Morganas! It looks like the crew will have to be tested before we planned. Those dreadnoughts are looking at the Spezia shipyard hungrily.
We cannot let her damage any of the ships there! Let's teach the Cattive Ragazze not to mess with my sisters!
@BATTLE
Capitano. Are we alone in your cabin? Is there any possibility of listening ears?
No, I don't think so. You would know better than I, though. These quarters are new to me.
I don't think anyone is listening in, but we should speak quietly, and not for long, just in case.
What's going on?
There are many things that I cannot talk about when we're out on deck, Capitano.
The Italian government are eager to keep their Belles close. The Prime Minister considers us a sign of the sanctity of his regime.
He is zealous in making sure the Belles are aligned with his party lines and uphold the cause of Italy.
Why? What did you do?
Nothing, aside from voice my opinions in the days following my awakening.
I've learned quickly that there are eyes and ears everywhere. Whatever I say publicly will be reported back to the government.

Fields.MenuText: You're right to be cautious.
I don't think you need to be worried while we're at sea.
Nobody onboard could be reporting back to the Italian government.

Fields.DialogueText: Grazie, Capitano. I'm glad you understand. They may have placed eyes among the crew, and I cannot be too careful. For everyone's sake.
You would think so, but I've learned quickly that the Prime Minister has eyes everywhere. Better for everyone's sakes that we remain careful.
I beg to differ, Capitano. Without a doubt, the Prime Minister has placed spies among my crew. I'm a valuable asset to them, as are all Belles.
Well, I suppose I understand your desire for discretion. You'll be honest with me, I hope.
Capitano, I fear we have spent too long in idle talk - there are Morganas creeping up on us!
They come first, I suppose.
@BATTLE
Especially when a certain Belle may have displayed signs of displeasure with the situation.
Leave your mountains, a stranger told to me! Follow me to the countryside, no more a mountain dweller be...
What was that you were singing, d'Aosta?
Capitano! Mi dispiace. I didn't hear you approach.
No need to snap to attention. It isn't inspection day.
It's a song about Aosta. My home.
That's where you get your name. Emmanuele Filiberto Duca d'Aosta.
It was silly - to give someone like me so grand a name.
What do you mean?
... I don't know, Capitano. Forgive me, I spoke without thinking.
I don't think any spies are listening in on us, if that's what you're worried about. We're not doing anything seditious. We're just a Belle and her captain, talking.
Talking can be more dangerous than you might know, Capitano. Words, and how they are spoken, are life and death in some places.
But enough of that. What of you, Capitano? Do you miss your home? Do you regret sailing away from it?

Fields.MenuText: I do. If it wasn't for the war, I would be back there now.
I could never stay in one place for long. I've always wanted to travel.
I don't look back.

Fields.DialogueText: ... The same goes for me. Though, I suppose, if it wasn't for the war, I might not have woken at all...
I have too. I was so disappointed when my sister and I were called back to Italy! But... I still get melancholy, leaving.
That makes sense, Capitano. I respect you for that.
I hate departures. I'm excited to see new lands. So much of the world I haven't seen! But...
You will miss your home, Aosta.
I'll miss Italy, Capitano. But it is our duty to obey our superiors, is it not?
@BATTLE
D'Aosta, whose portrait is that in the wardroom? I pass by it nearly every day, but have never taken the time to ask.
That's my namesake. Prince Emanuele Filiberto, Duke of Aosta. He was a great military commander - they called him the Undefeated Duke.
That's quite a legacy you have to follow.
Hah, I know. I don't know if I'm quite worthy. I hope I am.
I hope he would have been proud of me. I don't want to dishonor his name.

Fields.MenuText: I have no doubt you will live up to his name.
There's plenty of opportunity to live up to such deeds these days.
I don't like that picture being in the wardroom. It's strange.

Fields.DialogueText: Ah! Grazie - thank you, Capitano!
... It's unfortunate, but true. War isn't something to celebrate. We are only doing what we must.
... I'm afraid it's going to have to stay, Capitano. It's as much a part of me as any other part of the ship.
But enough talk about me - we have orders to hunt Cattive Ragazze, don't we?
That we do. They're to the southwest, according to the information we received from the Fleet.
I love a good hunt.
@BATTLE
D'Aosta! What are you doing up there? You'll hurt yourself!
One second, Capitano!
What did you say, Capitano?
You... oh. I forgot you could blink about the ship like that.
I prefer not to, honestly. It makes me feel a bit strange. But there's no quicker way of getting down from the mast!
What were you doing up there?
Just enjoying the view. Climbing is one of the pleasures of life.
Of course, climbing the mast is nowhere near as good as mountain climbing, but I can't very well abandon my duty to go climb the Matterhorn!

Fields.MenuText: I had no idea you had such a passion for it.
You shouldn't play around like that. You could get hurt.
You shouldn't be distracting the crew like that.

Fields.DialogueText: In Savoy, especially in the Aosta Valley, it's commonplace.
Don't worry about me! I never lose my footing.
I don't think I'm distracting them. But if you would prefer I stop, I will.
But I saw something when I was up there. Ships, on the horizon. I think they may be Morganas.
Why do you say that?
They weren't flying any flag, and they looked strange. I suppose we'll just have to chase them down and see.
@BATTLE
Capitano. Cattive Ragazze in nearby waters. They're likely headed towards the coast. Should we try to chase them off?
Our standing orders are to hinder the Morganas whenever we can. That group looks big, though... and is that a carrier?! Hm...
What do you think, d'Aosta?
I follow my orders, Capitano. My orders are to obey you and to defend Italy. I will trust your judgment.

Fields.MenuText: We should attack them. We have to protect the communities on the coast.
We should attack. Taking down their assets is important.
It's too risky.

Fields.DialogueText: I agree. I think it is a worthwhile risk.
Of course. Defending the coastal towns is important too.
Could be.
It looks like the decision might not be in our hands. They've spotted us!
Damn! Call all hands to stations!
@BATTLE
Augh! What condition are we in, Capitano? It's taking all my focus just keeping all the engines running correctly...
The engineers are doing their best to fix that as quickly as possibly. We're lucky you're not sinking.
Whew! I know. Believe me, I do.
And in the mountains, we make génépi with Artemisia and vodka. It's a wonderful liqueur. I'll have to share some with you at some point.
Are you giving my medical officers ideas, d'Aosta? They have enough bad ideas on their own, I trust.
Hah, nothing of the sort, Capitano! M. Delacroix, Miss Albertson, and I were just talking about traditional drinks in our countries. I have quite a respect for French wine.
Why are you blushing, d'Aosta?
I-I'm not! Trust me, I'm not promoting anything aside from responsible consumption of Fleet-appointed rations... unless it's an officer such as yourself, who can do as they like.
Rank has privileges. I have to borrow you for a moment.
Of course. What is it, Capitano? I'm sorry if I spoke out of turn.
It's nothing. I do hope you're not distracting my medical officers, however. Or anyone else. I swear I've seen you in conversation with almost every crew member on board today.
Just diverting them, Capitano. The aftermath of our last battle was hard on them. On all of us, but especially them.
... But what was it you wanted to tell me?

Fields.MenuText: I appreciate your efforts to keep up the crew's spirits, d'Aosta.
I'm surprised by how much you talk to the crew.
I'm not sure I approve of your fraternizing with the crew.

Fields.DialogueText: Grazie. I'm doing my best. I understand what many are feeling. It's difficult to leave behind one's home to fight such terrors.
They're a bit like my family, as are you. I've always loved my crews. We have to depend on each other.
They're my crew, just as much as you are my capitano. I have to get to know them. This is something you shouldn't stop me from doing.
I'm only trying to do what I can to help.
Hmm. Well, you certainly have charmed many people onboard. If only you could so easily charm the Morganas...
That would be a trick! But I have my armaments for the Morganas, and they're just as effective.
And now that you mention it, I think we might have to charm Morganas out of the idea of attacking us. I can sense some nearby.
I see them. Sounds like the lookout does, too. Do you have that winning smile of yours?
Certamente. Always, Capitano.
@BATTLE
Capitano, do you have any idea of what motivates the Morganas? I was talking to some of our officers at dinner, but they didn't have anything other than speculation.
I'm afraid I can't give a better answer than they could. We have little clue as to what motivates them, aside from some form of conquest.
Do you think they have a command structure? Do you think someone gives them orders?
Honestly, I have no idea. That's something the Fleet would give a great deal to know. But why do you ask?
I was just thinking... perhaps some of the Morganas are under orders they don't agree with. Perhaps they attack because it is their duty, not because they get any enjoyment or gain from it.

Fields.MenuText: That's a valid point, d'Aosta. It's entirely possible. It doesn't change the fact they are attacking us, however.
I think they go out of their way to be brutal. That doesn't indicate unwillingness to commit violence.
I have no sympathy for those that do what the Morganas do.

Fields.DialogueText: I know. It was just something that was bothering me.
That's true. They do seem to enjoy it. There's no doubt they are awful. I suppose I shouldn't worry about it.
... That's fair, Capitano. I didn't mean I did. I just... I was wondering.
In the end, it doesn't matter. We have to fight back.
I'm not going to roll over and let the Cattive Ragazze pillage and burn.
It sounds like someone on the watch spotted Morganas. I suppose we might be able to glean something of her motivations from this fight.
@BATTLE
Capitano! Look out!
@BATTLE
Capitano! Are you all right?
I... what? What happened? We... we won, didn't we? I remember watching the Morganas begin to flee...
You... you fell overboard.
I... what?

Fields.MenuText: How am I back up here?
I guess that explains why I'm soaked.
I did not fall overboard.

Fields.DialogueText: I jumped in after you, Capitano, and kept you afloat until the crew fished us out. You must have been stunned by hitting the water, because you were sinking like a rock.
Of course. You must have been stunned by hitting the water, and you were sinking like a rock until I got to you.
You did, Capitano! I had to jump in and pull you out. You were lucky you didn't fall too far away from the ship for me to reach you.
I don't know how you managed to fall... I wasn't looking, and the next thing I knew, you were in the water.
Ugh...
Here, drink some brandy. It'll warm you up. You're looking pale.
You have... a keg of brandy?
It comes in handy in the alpine weather. I'm a mountain girl, after all. It's a necessity.
Ever considered that you may be a Saint Bernard, and not, in fact, a ship?
Hah, Capitano, don't tease me like that! Mountain dogs don't actually carry brandy. Mountain girls, however, have a taste for it.
... Though I always have loved Saint Bernards. Do you think we could keep a dog onboard?
... I'll consult the Fleet protocols.
I think you should get into warm clothes first and get some rest. That was quite a fall.
I heard we received orders to make port in Monaco from the Fleet, Capitano.
We did. We're supposed to take a representative of the Monégasque government to the Protection Force headquarters in Spain.
... d'Aosta? What's wrong? You look pale.
The Italian government will have a problem with using me to transport an official of a nominally French country... especially Monaco.
They will be displeased Monaco is being included in the Fleet to begin with.
Unfortunately, or fortunately, depending on who you ask, Mussolini can't give orders to the Fleet anymore than any president or prime minister can.
That's true. But if he persuaded the King... I couldn't ignore an order from my King.

Fields.MenuText: Your government will play nice with the Fleet's wishes. Don't worry.
Even for me?
You're coming dangerously close to insubordination.

Fields.DialogueText: I can only hope. They are often... challenging, in the eyes of foreign powers.
No, Capitano! Never. I'm only stating the truth.
Do you want to shirk our duty and press it off on another ship?
... No. I want to do all that I can to defeat the Cattive Ragazze! Politics is all above my head, but I understand that this would aid that goal.
You've made that claim twice now, and I'm not sure it's true. So you want to defeat the Morganas?
I wish to do as my King and the house of Savoy have commanded me, and that is to defend our home from the Cattive Ragazze.
Those are your orders, but how about you personally? Belles can have their own feelings, can't they?
La pomma euntanaye se varde pa.
What did you say?
Ah, it's... it's a phrase from Savoy. The bitten apple does not care. I have my orders, and I must follow them. I'm a ship, after all, I'm steered by the will of my King and Capitano.
Somehow I don't think it's as simple as that.
That's how it must be. Capitano, I fear that Monaco has things to worry about other than Mussolini. Some of those naughty Morganas are creeping into their waters.
It's our duty to step in, isn't it?
@BATTLE
D'Aosta! You seem to have charmed our Monégasque guest! He was gushing to me about your skills as a hostess.
I'm just doing my duty as a Belle. It would be rude not to play the host to any guest we bring onboard.
Would you mind stepping into your cabin with me, Capitano? I want to go over our route one more time.
Of course... what is it, d'Aosta? You've got the route memorized. You've been studying for hours...
Please don't call attention to my friendliness towards the delegate. I'm worried that my minders might take it the wrong way.

Fields.MenuText: Of course. I'll mind my words.
You really believe there are spies onboard?
I don't like the idea of having spies onboard.

Fields.DialogueText: Grazie, Capitano. I'm sorry to be such a trouble.
I do. I know there are. The prime minister doesn't trust me, as the Americans would say, "as far as he could throw me."
I don't either, but I'm not sure how we could get rid of them. We'll just have to be careful.
I'm sorry... Oh! I think there are Cattive Ragazze nearby. I felt something...
Through the porthole... Look! They're sailing along the coast! It looks like they're going for one of those French coastal towns...
We can't leave them defenseless. I-I mean, we should help, if we can. For the good of the Fleet.
You're right.
@BATTLE
I'm glad to see our Monégasque friend safe to Spain, but it looks like you were right about your government being a problem.
You read the correspondence from Italy? They want us back in port.
I know. They're angry we went out of our way to defend the French coast... claiming it was a reckless use of resources.

Fields.MenuText: That was no reckless use of resources. We were defending the populace against Morganas!
We did harm to Morganas. That's what we're supposed to be doing.
Perhaps chasing those Morganas was a mistake.

Fields.DialogueText: Exactly. We were doing our duty.
We were following our orders! We couldn't exactly pass enemy targets by. We did not disobey any orders.
It wasn't. We weren't disobeying our orders.
Morganas that close to the French coast would have soon become a problem for Italy anyway.
We're part of the Protection Force. We're supposed to be defending all countries, not just your country of origin.
I know. I fear that... my government is jealous and suspicious of the use of their Belles, especially since you don't fall under their direct command.
Do they treat all their Belles and Captains like this?! Yanking them back to heel whenever they attack?
I don't know if they are so cautious with every Belle.
You're lucky you don't have to communicate with them to ask before attacking every time you attack. That was something they considered.
Italy is not so rich in ships or shipyards as some of the other countries in this conflict... and they have grown very attached to their Belles very quickly.
Hmm. There's nothing to be done but go back to Italy, then. Will they try to take you from me?
I... I hadn't thought of that. I don't think so. I hope not. I... I don't think they could.
Capitano, it looks like we've picked up followers since departing the Spanish port. They... don't look too friendly. I think we'll have to draw further ire from Italy before we return home.
Of course. It is our job, after all.
@BATTLE
Capitano.
d'Aosta! Are you all right? d'Aosta?
They will not try to take you from me, Capitano.
What's that paper on your chest? It says 'si'? It's pinned to your jacket...
Don't touch it! ...It is part of the terms of me being here. It is a reminder, of who I am, and who I serve. Where my loyalties lie.
Where do your loyalties lie?
I serve my King, and it is my King's will that I am here. I will do anything for the House of Savoy.
They have commanded me to fight, and so I do. It is my King's will that I fight, so I chose you to fight alongside me. They cannot take that from me.
d'Aosta...
I have been reminded of my loyalties. I have reminded them of the duty that I have, as a ship. I'm not a girl, not truly, and I'm not an idol to be kept on a shelf. I can't stay home in Aosta.
... I can't even return to Aosta.

Fields.MenuText: What's wrong? What happened?
You look wrecked. What did they do to you?
Pull yourself together, d'Aosta.

Fields.DialogueText: Exactly what I said. Nothing is wrong. Please let me be, Capitano.
Nothing more than remind me of what is right and what is my duty. Please leave me alone, Capitano.
... Yes, Capitano.
You're a Belle. You're my Belle. That's what I know about you. You're not a girl, and you're not just a ship.
... Yes, Capitano.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
I heard you've infiltrated my kitchen, d'Aosta.
Capitano? I wouldn't use such a word to describe it.
My chef has taken quite a liking to you. He says you were behind that interesting dish at last night's dinner. It certainly delighted my officers.
Ah! I noticed. I'm glad. I enjoy it, and... I'm glad to share. It's called Seupa Freida. It's made of dry black bread, sugar, and wine. Did you like it?

Fields.MenuText: It was the highlight of the night.
It was a novel taste.
It wasn't much to my taste, to be honest, but there is no doubt it was a work of art.

Fields.DialogueText: Ah! Capitano, you flatter me!
Hmm, don't tease me like that! I know you liked it.
Ah, well, you can't win everything. Your officers certainly did, at least.
I'm glad it made your chef happy. He's been quite appreciative of the help. If we sail closer to the coast, perhaps I'll be able to shoot some fowl to put on the table as well!
You can shoot?
Capitano, you know the capabilities of my guns quite well.
I know you can shoot Morganas with your cannons, but I don't think they'd be too useful for shooting down wildlife.
Hah! No, you're right. I know how to use a hunting rifle, Capitano. I'm quite the hunter. You have to be, up in the mountains.
... Back in Aosta?
Of course.
You really miss it, don't you?
I doubt I'll get to hunt bird anytime soon... but I do think I can hear Cattive Ragazze trailing their fingers in the sea nearby... We should be able to pick up their trail.
I suppose we can try to poach Morganas.
@BATTLE
Capitano, they're back!
I received a report of an American ship fighting with them a week or so ago. Our enemy? She's called Sin, and that is her escort.
Aprì la partia, lo revendzo!
I didn't quite catch that, d'Aosta.
After the game, revenge! We'll repay them for those they took from us last time.

Fields.MenuText: I hope your optimism holds true.

Fields.DialogueText: They look like they're limping along. They must have tangled with some of our allies.

Fields.MenuText: Best motivation for violence. Revenge!
Keep a cool head. We have to make rational decisions with an enemy that's this dangerous.

Fields.DialogueText: And my hull will hold, too.
Hmm...
Understood, Capitano.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
Capitano, when we make port at Porto Torres, could you pick me up some newspapers?
Most likely. What sort of newspapers? Italian, I presume?
Yes, please. Grazie! I've worn the last few thin reading them.
Can't you communicate with other Belles to stay current on world events?
I can, but I like to read the Italian news. There's... a great deal more than than just what is printed on the page.
Besides, it's good to hear of my King and the rest of the house of Savoy. It's good to know they are well.
... I worry about my King. You know of his claims on Ethiopia and Albania? He calls himself an Emperor, now. They've elevated Mussolini to the rank of First Marshal of the Empire...
I should not question the judgment of those above me... but overreaching ambition is wrong.

Fields.MenuText: You would think one country would be enough for a king.
There's certainly a lot of overreaching ambition around these days.
I think conquest is admirable.

Fields.DialogueText: That's what I think. He has Savoy, and the whole of Italy besides.
I know. It doesn't bode well for us, Capitano.
I suppose we're going to have to agree to disagree.
For me, Savoy is more than enough. But... I should not question the will of kings and such.
Unfortunately, there isn't much we can do about it.
Those Morganas that are making their way towards us, on the other hand...
@BATTLE
Capitano, I'm sorry to disturb you in your quarters. May I come in?
Of course. It's no trouble, d'Aosta. What's going on?
Do you trust me? I need you to trust me.

Fields.MenuText: I trust you absolutely.
I trust you, so long as you remain trustworthy.
You can't just spring that question on me. You need to explain yourself.

Fields.DialogueText: Grazie. I trust you, too.
That's fair enough. I trust you.
... I understand. I will. Because I trust you.
I think I was right in my suspicions about a spy being onboard this ship. A spy who is passing information back to the Prime Minister's men.
I was walking the deck tonight, and I happened to see something.
I saw one of the crew sneak off the ship, to meet with someone on the harbor dock. I saw them exchange papers, and then the crew member came back.
Did you see who it was? The gender, or rank, at least?
No, Capitano. It wasn't someone on watch at the time, I know that. The light was too low to make out their features.
I... should have stepped out and confronted them, but before I could make contact they had gone below deck.
There's nothing in that exchange that says they are definitely Italian spies.
I think they must be, Capitano. When I was spoken to by those Italian officials, after we defended the French coast... they admonished me for speaking Valdôtain.
Why? Why do they care if you speak your native language?
We Belles, we're supposed to be symbols of the new regime, and of Italian unity. Speaking a language that the government wants to die... doesn't fit that role.
I see. I'm not sure I like the idea of having a spy onboard, passing our every word back to anyone.
We should-- what is that?!
The Porto Torres harbor alarm. They must have sighted Morganas nearby!
We must aid them, Capitano!
@BATTLE
Capitano... have you read the telegraph that was transmitted for me?
Not yet. I didn't think it was polite to read another's correspondence. What did it say?
I shouldn't have spoken so freely, before, when speaking about the King. Or let myself slip into my native tongue...
Are your handlers angry?
Very. It was all thinly-veiled threats, and accusations of unpatriotic intent... even treason.
They reminded me that I am a symbol of Italy, and if I want to remain on the seas, I must represent Italy correctly, by being properly Italian...
... and not voicing "seditious thoughts" against my King. I would never betray my King! I'm loyal to him! I just...
d'Aosta?
... I just have to be more careful, Capitano. I've let myself become careless, because it feels like it should be safe here, with the crew, and you... but it isn't.
Not with the Prime Minister's eyes everywhere.

Fields.MenuText: That's no way for you to live. We have to get rid of that spy.
You should be worrying about fighting the Morganas, not looking over your shoulder all the time. That spy hinders our work.
I don't like being watched. We need to get rid of that spy.

Fields.DialogueText: ... Get rid of them? I don't know how we could do that. I... I don't know if I can even think about it...
... They do. I don't know how we could get rid of them. I don't know if it would be right.
... Is that the right thing to do?
We can't kill them.
Of course not. But there are plenty of reasons to have a sailor reassigned, or even discharged from the service.
We just have to figure out who they are.
That's the problem.
Deal with this problem first. Look!
@BATTLE
d'Aosta, is everything all right? I had one of the hands come to me and tell me you were down here crying.
... E-Everything's fine, Capitano! I don't know... what they were thinking...
You have been crying. Your eyes are red.
No. Even if I was, I don't know why a crew member would feel the need to bother you with such a trivial thing.
They care about you, just like you care about them.
... They're kind. There's nothing wrong. I just miss Italy. I let that homesickness catch up with me, and I didn't want to cry in front of the crew, so I came here.

Fields.MenuText: I understand. I miss my home too.
You miss Italy, or Aosta?
You should focus on the job we have.

Fields.DialogueText: You do? I guess it's natural for everyone. It's silly, I know, to miss something I haven't really ever seen. But the Aosta valley, the castle, the mountains... I can see it all, Capitano.
... It's foolish, to miss something I've never seen. Truly, I've never set foot in Aosta, but I know it like the back of my hand. I miss it, Capitano.
I know. It's foolish to miss something I've never seen. I'm a Belle, and I have a duty to fulfill, to my King and people.
I'm sorry for getting distracted, Capitano.
It's all right. We all are sometimes. But we have a spy to deal with, and you should be on your guard. We got word of Morganas in this area.
Speak of the devil, and the horns will appear. I think they're coming closer.
@BATTLE
I miss it with all my being.
Capitano, could we speak in your cabin? I've received some information on the spies from one of my sisters.
Of course. What did your sister tell you, d'Aosta?
I've got a lot of sisters, actually. Well, half-sisters at least. Not all of them are Belles like me, but we still have... an understanding.
But she said some of them have spies onboard. She helped me get a sense of what to look for.
They're probably not men or women from the Regia Marina, because that's a bit obvious. They're not likely French seamen either.
That makes sense. I've been thinking about our little problem as well. It couldn't have been one of the sailors on watch at the time.
No. So no Italians, no French, and no sailors who were on-watch... but that still leaves a lot of crew members.
At least not so many as before. How regularly do you think they are sending information back to your government?
I'm not sure. Likely they're doing it when we make port.
We could isolate likely candidates, and have them followed by trustworthy crew members when we make port.
Do you have crew you trust absolutely?

Fields.MenuText: Of course. Many of them.
I have a few I would trust implicitly.
To be honest, no.

Fields.DialogueText: Many? Are you absolutely sure of their loyalty? This plan may require trusting too many people.
Can you be absolutely, entirely sure they aren't spies? Spies can be very talented at gaining the trust of others.
... I don't think I do either, aside from you.
Hmm. Perhaps we need a different plan.
We should talk about this later, Capitano. I can smell Morganas nearby trying to get the drop on us.
We can't let them do that, can we?
@BATTLE
Capitano, I have a question for you. If I may ask.

Fields.MenuText: Of course, ask what you want. What is it?

Fields.DialogueText: There's no one listening in on us.
Well... wait, what was that?
The lookout! One of the crew on watch must have seen Morganas.
I'll think on your question, but it will have to wait.
@BATTLE
Speak freely. Where do your loyalties lie?
*ALARM*

Fields.MenuText: Must be one hell of a question.
My answer is no. I don't think we're ready to get married.

Fields.DialogueText: Hahaha! You're absurd, Capitano. My question is serious, but I'll admit that laugh helped me calm down a bit.
It's important to me.
Here goes...
Capitano, we're making port in an Italian city tonight, aren't we?
If all goes well hunting these Morganas.
Good. I have an idea... deny the crew shore leave today. No matter how much they grumble. Whoever sneaks off the ship, we'll know they're the spy.
They might choose to lie low and be cautious. Especially if they don't have anything to report.
Oh, I'll give them something to report, Capitano. After this fight.
@BATTLE
"Qui senne lo veun recolte la tempéta! Sow the storm and reap the tempest, you ill-mannered thing! RUN like the coward you are!"
"The world has NO USE for those who try to usurp the rights and the sovereignty of others!!!"
d'Aosta... are you all right?
I think that should give our spy enough to think about, if they heard me.
*ALARM*

Fields.MenuText: Good plan!
The whole crew heard that.
Was that speech from the heart?

Fields.DialogueText: Only the spy matters, Capitano.
A necessary collateral effect.
Grazie!
Now we watch to see who takes the bait...
Capitano! How did your meeting with the Fleet brass go?
Sit down, d'Aosta. You look like you're about to faint.
Getting rid of that spy means the difference between freedom and imprisonment in some dry dock!
... I still can't believe it was your chef. I guess.... I was too free with my words with him. I underestimated him, and let down my guard.

Fields.MenuText: I was surprised too. A lesson for both of us, I suppose.
I suppose it makes sense, now that I think of it. He did seem eager to get close to you.
I never liked him.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes. I'll have to be more cautious in the future.
He did. And I let him, because he reminded me of home.
I did. I was a fool, Capitano.
It's not your fault. Getting close to people is what spies are supposed to do.
At any rate, we won't have to worry about him anymore. I was honest with one of the admirals. I told him what a disruption this was, and how it was interfering with the defense of these waters.
The admiralty took it seriously, understood the imposition, and took the man into custody. He won't be reporting back to the Italian government any time soon.
Ah, Capitano! Thank you! You're my hero.
Hah, you're welcome! This didn't happen without a cost, however. We have an assignment.
Morganas have been raiding French shipment off the coast of Nice. They're rather small, but they've been quite a hazard.
I don't like bullies. Let's hunt them down!
@BATTLE
Ah, d'Aosta. It's been a busy few days. How are you doing?
Well, Capitano. I just wanted to ask you, if it's all right, about that question again.
Ah, yes, I remember. You asked where my loyalties lie. Why are you checking the door?
Making sure we don't have any unwanted listeners. Just because we got rid of one spy doesn't mean we can't be cautious.
That's true. Anyway, I've been thinking about your question.

Fields.MenuText: My loyalties lie with my country, and humanity. We have to defeat the Morganas.
My loyalties lie with my friends and family. I need to protect them.
I don't know where my loyalties lie. Things aren't really neat and clean-cut for me.

Fields.DialogueText: Admirable, Capitano. That's a goal we should all share.
I understand that. That's very noble.
... I don't know where mine lie either, Capitano. It can be so confusing.
I... I love my King. I love Aosta. I love the house of Savoy. But... I don't know if I love Italy. How can I be a Belle of Italy and not love her?
Loyalty and love is complicated, d'Aosta. What matters right now that you're doing the right things, fighting the Morganas.
You're right. There are really only two things I'm sure of right now. The need to fight off the Cattive Ragazze, and...
Capitano, call all hands! I can sense our enemies nearby!
@BATTLE
I have a surprise for you, d'Aosta.
A surprise? What is it?
A gift. Two gifts, actually.
Capitano? Really? Thank you! What... what are they?
Come with me. First of all, I thought you could use better quarters. You're a Belle, and you require some quality for your own private space.
Ah! Capitano! These are your old chef's quarters!
I don't really need my own chef. Especially after that last one. You should be comfortable and feel secure, d'Aosta. This ship is yours more than it is anyone else's.
Ah! Thank you so much, Capitano! Grazie!
And my other gift to you... well, I had a bit of trouble keeping this one a surprise.
She was very eager to meet you. I'm still not sure whether dogs are allowed under regulations, but if you won't tell, neither will I.
Ah! Aw, is she a Saint Bernard puppy? She's so small, Capitano! ... You know she'll get very big, don't you?
Of course. You'll have to make sure she gets enough exercise, and isn't under the feet of the crew, of course.
But... I thought you might enjoy having a little piece of home onboard. She's a proper mountain dog, from Aosta, at least according to the man I bought her from.
I don't know what to say. Nobody... nobody has ever given me a gift before... let alone such wonderful things! Mille grazie, Capitano.
It's nothing. It's good to see you smile. But do, please, keep the puppy out from under foot. And give her a good name.
Ah, speaking of names... You don't have to keep calling me d'Aosta, you know. It's the most formal part of my name, but we're more familiar now.
You could call me Duca, if you like, or just Emanuele.

Fields.MenuText: Duca suits you. You're quite noble!
I like Emanuele.
